data.title: Catalog
data.meta_description: Clarence Webb manages High Bluff Mineral Springs, a health spa, and spikes the "natural water" with lithia, sulfur and other medical curatives in order to attract wealthy hypochondriacs. When Gladys Saunders, fresh from college, inherits the spa, Clarence makes romantic overtures, but she turns him down, even though her late father had assumed that she and Clarence would someday marry. When Gladys becomes interested in Dr. Sherwood, a visitor to the spa, Clarence threatens to confess to medicating the waters, and thereby ruin Gladys' business, if she continues her relationship with the doctor. However, Sherwood, who has overhead all this, tells Gladys that he can cure the spa's patients without drugs, through diet and exercise, and succeeds spectacularly with his new regimen, which defuses Clarence's threat and allows them to proceed with their romance without him.
data.text:
Drugged Waters was one of sixteen Universal releases for the week of 20 March 1916, the 18 March 1916 Moving Picture World announced. Among the week's other Universal films were seven comedies, six dramas, and a comedy-drama.

Drugged Waters was Gloria Fonda's last film. She worked on several movies with director-actor William Dowlan and his wife, writer Leonoa Ainsworth.

In his 11 March 1916 Moving Picture World review, Robert C. McElravy wrote: "The sanitarium scenes, in which a large number of men and women patients are put through daily baths and exercises, are amusing, but strung out too much. More villainy on the part of the manager would have kept the plot stirring to better advantage....The rainstorm scenes make a natural and pleasing feature." The 11 March 1916 Motion Picture News reviewer, Peter Milne, wrote, "As for length, five reels is about two too many and there is constant repetition of the same action. New York Clipper called the picture "three reels too long."

The National Film Preservation Board (NFPB) included this film on its list of Lost U.S. Silent Feature Films as of February 2021. ...

More Less

Drugged Waters was one of sixteen Universal releases for the week of 20 March 1916, the 18 March 1916 Moving Picture World announced. Among the week's other Universal films were seven comedies, six dramas, and a comedy-drama.

Drugged Waters was Gloria Fonda's last film. She worked on several movies with director-actor William Dowlan and his wife, writer Leonoa Ainsworth.

In his 11 March 1916 Moving Picture World review, Robert C. McElravy wrote: "The sanitarium scenes, in which a large number of men and women patients are put through daily baths and exercises, are amusing, but strung out too much. More villainy on the part of the manager would have kept the plot stirring to better advantage....The rainstorm scenes make a natural and pleasing feature." The 11 March 1916 Motion Picture News reviewer, Peter Milne, wrote, "As for length, five reels is about two too many and there is constant repetition of the same action. New York Clipper called the picture "three reels too long."

The National Film Preservation Board (NFPB) included this film on its list of Lost U.S. Silent Feature Films as of February 2021.

Less

Clarence Webb manages High Bluff Mineral Springs, a health spa, and spikes the "natural water" with lithia, sulfur and other medical curatives in order to attract wealthy hypochondriacs. When Gladys Saunders, fresh from college, inherits the spa, Clarence makes romantic overtures, but she turns him down, even though her late father had assumed that she and Clarence would someday marry. When Gladys becomes interested in Dr. Sherwood, a visitor to the spa, Clarence threatens to confess to medicating the waters, and thereby ruin Gladys' business, if she continues her relationship with the doctor. However, Sherwood, who has overhead all this, tells Gladys that he can cure the spa's patients without drugs, through diet and exercise, and succeeds spectacularly with his new regimen, which defuses Clarence's threat and allows them to proceed with their romance without him.
